A true wireless setup does not actually exist. You still need cables to charge your peripherals, or you have to use replaceable batteries which are often too heavy or bulky for some applications. Lil drilling tip. After you've managed to start drilling a slightly larger hole and the bit hard stops, hitting your monitor. Restarting can be easier if you run the bit backwards for a second. That hard stop is the bit digging instead of cutting. The back ward drilling will smooth out the dig spots and make mid hole restarts easier.

Wanna know what the problem with hot-glueing power bricks is?




They get hot.

@Christian Permalino However in the configuration he described the power bricks are constantly loading the glue with their weight. Not a lot of heat is necessary in order to transform hot glue from a solid to a just very, very gooey liquid. Meaning the heat cycles and constant load will weaken the glue joints over time leading to failure.
They don't get that hot though

Has Linus tried double sided velcro tape? They make tape that can hold 15 pounds. A couple of strips should do it.
I've done the screws w heavy gauge copper wire to also tie down stuff too.

Use hot-glue and a pea-sized dollop silicone adhesive the hot glue will hold while the silicone sets then it not coming off without a chisel and a light tap with a hammer, beware too much silicone will be much harder to get off and I wouldn't to it if the underside of the desk is something really porous like particleboard unless you have practiced and got your amount of hot glue to silicone figured out. Using hot glue well can be an art using the right temperature and amount is very important an in most if not all cases hot glue is nonpermanent by design. It is most useful because it's quick and sticks to almost anything semi-permanently for things like crafting and prototyping. I came across the idea of alternating dots of hot glue and silicon in the countertop biz and have successfully applied it to many other DIY type adventures and most with great success. Any it's a secret handyman technique I wanted to share the hopefully someone can get so use out of.

Use 3M Black tape to hold power bricks.
Hot glue fails on the table because of the solvent used to clean the surface after production. It is oily and will never clean off 100%. The 3m tape is made from an oil based product, and you will likely never remove the power brick again. In fact, if your house is it with an Atom Bomb, or Neutron beam from space aliens... Your power bricks will survive and still be mounted onto a piece of your desk... Somewhere in the next province over...
I recommend a forstner bit or a hole saw bit for drilling large holes like that. A little safer and easier to use.

There is a nice trick which might work nicely for sticking things up under the table (like powerbricks you mentioned) which comes from knifemaking when there is a need to align handle for drilling holes and then easily get rid of connection without damaging or contaminating any surface. Instead of using the glue itself, which might not hold easily to different surfaces and leave marks, they stick the tape for both metal and wood (like a silvertape or any other, whichever works best) and than apply super glue in-between them. The connection is super strong, if you want to get rid of it you can just twist it to break the bond but the cherry on top is that after breaking you can just peel the tape off and you have no marks on any surface (brick and table in this case). Hope it would be helpful for someone's cable management project :)

You can infact use wireless headphones with the go XLR with a small work around.  Run the headphone output from the go XLR into the "line in" input of your pc.  Then open Sounds "found in the right click menu of the speaker icon in your dock". Go to recording tab and right-click on the "line-in" input and open properties.  You can then chose to monitor this source on the wireless headphones. A small complicated work around (please note there may be a very small delay due to what i assume is processing of some kind).

Linus, gonna throw you a Construction Tip; hope ya don‚Äôt mind(love the comments from DavidüòÇ)
For drilling holes in FINISHED work, using speedbor bits NOT GOOD IDEA, just use normal paddle.
Secondly, start on top and bottom in reverse for a few seconds to ‚Äúcut‚Äù material, than when go forward making the hole....will help prevent tear out. Can also use some painters tape & drill through bottom to top (finished service will have tape) to ‚Äúhelp‚Äù prevent tear out. Can also use Auger, and Linus, gonna throw you a tip.
For drilling holes in FINISHED work, using speedbor bits NOT GOOD IDEA (I.E.: Bosch Daredevil, Diablo Speedemon), just use the classic standby Irwin Speedbor paddle bitsüëçüèª
Secondly, start on top and bottom in reverse for a few seconds to ‚Äúcut‚Äù material, than when go forward making the hole....will help prevent tear out. Can also use some painters tape & drill through bottom to top (finished service will have tape) to ‚Äúhelp‚Äù prevent tear out. Can also use Auger bits, Forstner bits, & even hole saws(again use hole saw in reverse to score material & help prevent tear out, still might happen depending on material; but might not be as bad).....but imo, regular paddle bits are good, cheap, & easy to find.
Been drilling holes in finished cabinets, tables, desks, etc....for over 20 years. Hope this helps someone‚úåüèº

If you ever need to expand a hole with a spade bit or hole saw, grab a piece of scrap wood and drill your expanded hole in that first. Then clamp that piece of wood with your new bigger hole over the top of the smaller hole. The wood will act like a template/guide and prevent the bit from wandering.

Protip: When you have to step up a spade bit take a little piece of scrap wood and drill a hole with the larger spade bit in it. Then use that scrap with the hole and line up over the old smaller hole (clamp down the scrap if possible). Then you can use the scrap piece with the hole as a guide for enlarging the hole below it. No need to destroy your fingers.

You need wires for charging you say? I SAY NO!
Do what I have done:
-Buy the QI-pads from IKEA which you can mount level in the desk. Put desk pad over, so they are invisible.
-Any peripherals (keyboard in my case) which haven't got QI-charging: Get one of those QI-adapter pads which is sold for phones with at he connector of choice (in my case micro USB), put it in the device, tape it underneath and place it on the charging pad.

I have put a charging pad underneath my keyboard in the middle and one in each top corner of my deskpad for charging mouse, keyboard and phone. No visible cables on my desk and no wired charging required.

I hate cable management, but I hated the disconnecting wifi, BT headset with scratching noises when some machine works, disconnecting wireless mouse and keyboards while gaming more. Cableless is maybe an option when you are the only one that use it, but in an area with a high amount of other users it's unusable. I live in an apartment building with about 20 flats. When I activate bluetooth on my mobile I got about 15 devices that are not mine and in Wifi there are about 25 networks. There is even a fridge with its own network. I used to have lag and disconnects in games and while working because of the other networks. You share band width even with the networks that are not yours but in the same channels. With wires the problems are gone and I got to laugh when my neighbours whine about bad internet connection.. And one thing to think about - how much energy get lost because of using wireless ? Using wires is better for the environment.

@Canada Jones As I said before, it's all relative depending on what you use it for. If you're going to just be playing things like GTAO, Minecraft, etc., then just using a controller or random mouse from Walmart would be fine for that. For someone who would actually be willing to spend the money to buy something like the mouse in this video, those options are shit. It's not 100% just my opinion, since it's not like I'd go to a random channel with someone editing code or designing websites and chastise them for using some run-of-the-mill mouse from HP, but because this mouse is meant for specific uses like esports and FPS, it's why I am belittling his mouse. Not just that, but because his idea to bring up the battery life of the mouse to say it's better or not. Of course he didn't actually mean that, but his first comment strongly suggested that and is why I even started this. Now of course, if he worded it better originally to suggest that this mouse is overkill for what he does day-to-day and that he'd rather stick with a mouse that has the battery life he talked about and the technology in it that some fancy sensors, wireless tech, and other hoopla that, admittedly, most users don't really give a damn about, then I wouldn't have said anything.
Regarding me just saying it's shit right off the bat, that's because, after ~10 years on YouTube, I've grown the understand that people hate "walls of text/paragraphs" and will use that to dismiss an argument or even read the comment at all. So just saying, "it's shit," might have been too harsh, but it's what would convey my message quickest and most efficiently; since for people looking at the mouse in the video as a potential purchase, they'd never even think about the mice you guys have brought up since battery life, while important, isn't enough of a reason to sacrifice the technology built into the mouse itself. And if battery life is truly such a problem for people looking into this mouse, they would instead opt for a wireless mouse that'd have the same sensors, weight, etc. rather than getting an HP, Dell, or Microsoft wireless mouse with batteries that'd last years. Of course not everyone agrees, but there's a reason why "gaming" and higher end mice exist, and that's because there's a market for them with people looking for the best mice to help give them any advantage they can get, whether it's truly better or just placebo. Otherwise, companies like Razer and Logitech wouldn't exist in the first place and everyone would just go and buy whatever has the most RGB or whatever mouse fits their weight, size, and grip type requirements (if they even play the types of games where such things matter).
I get it, I used to be the type that just played games on random HP mice from Walmart and not cared about any of the bells and whistles since I never did anything that needed such things 5+ years ago. But things are different now due to what I do, since now those cheap mice I used for Minecraft and singleplayer story games are no longer adequate and would make my experience miserable. It's the same way for 60hz refresh rate displays, audiophile headphones vs. "gaming" headphones vs. cheap $10 headphones, and mechanical vs. membrane keyboards. They all serve their purposes, but for select people, select items are required and that's just that. Not making fun of anyone for what they use, but just saying what's true. Like I aforementioned, I'm calling his mouse shit because of where he mentioned it, for a direct comparison between his mouse and the mouse in the video would show the many, many flaws that detail why there is a price difference, but also why battery life is so shit on the more expensive mouse. His mouse works perfectly fine for him and isn't shit to him because of what he uses it for, but that's not what people actually looking to buy this mouse would think. But hey, obviously this video reaches more markets then what it's advertising for is meant to reach, so I can't assume anyone here is actually in the market to buy such a mouse. But for those who are, then I can hope they see my original, albeit rude, comment about calling his mouse shit. Not because it is a shit mouse, but because it's a shit mouse for people who'd buy this video's mouse. (I feel like I'm on loop; anyone getting this feeling of d√©j√† vu, as well?)

I've no idea about the quality of that mouse, but I have a Logitech wireless mouse from about 9 years ago that I've been using on a regular basis since then. Not only that, but my daily desktop mouse is an HP cheapo pack-in. I've played many games on both mice, from Minecraft to Getting Over It with Bennett Foddy, and while they may not be suitable for competitive FPS play, they have been perfectly sufficient. I've never noticed any problem with using these mice for gaming, with both basically using no-name garbage sensors, so while they may be bad compared to the best modern mouse, I don't think it's justified to call them, or that Microsoft mouse for that matter, shit. You are of course entitled to your opinion, but I personally think it'd be better if you made clear it was your opinion. Simply saying that "it's shit" gives a more negative image than I feel is deserving, though, of course, you may disagree.

Arbitrary because it also depends on use, which no doubt differs from their test and your own.
I bought some cheap mouse like 3 years ago and it still works on the alkaline battery that came with it, probably because I barely use it :D

@hrq007 "One man's trash is another's treasure" also fits here... kind of. Although I understand your displeasure with me calling it shit, you can take it the same way as if someone who was driving a Mercedes-Benz SLS AMG were to talk shit about your car that you absolutely love and/or think of as perfectly adequate/suitable for you. Although not entirely similar since I sincerely doubt most drivers of cars of that price range or higher actually take their cars out to tracks to enjoy them everyday or even make use of all the luxury features while, with mice, it's easier to make full use of the technology built into it without just buying it as a tool to express wealth or for your own aesthetic pleasure.
Honestly, there's no point to all of this since it basically boils down to this: get what you want if you can afford it without sacrifice or worry and have no need for anything better if those better qualities are wasted due to lack of necessity. Whether it's a $10, $30, $60, or $150 mouse, there's always someone who will call it shit, whether or not they have a right to do so. Just as we both can call the $10 mouse shit because of its flaws, the owner of that $10 mouse can call your mouse shit, my mouse shit, and the $150 mouse shit because they cost much more and he doesn't need anything that those mice provide that his mouse doesn't already give him. Me calling your mouse shit in the original comment was not for the entirety of the mouse being shit, because, as you originally wrote, the battery life alone can be used as a reason to buy your mouse over the mouse in the video, but for the fact that your mouse would be considered shit by anyone looking to buy the mouse in this video. This mouse is catered towards a select group of individuals, so to people not in that group, this mouse can be called shit for the price, lack of battery life, or anything else they find fault in it because it doesn't fit their needs (i.e. 20+ extra buttons on the side of the mouse, a joystick built into the mouse, a scroll wheel that can be unlocked for infinite scroll, weights that can be added or taken out to change the weight, etc.).

Sorry again for "wall of text," but here's a tl;dr: every opinion is subjective and every item can be considered either good or shit depending on the person's need for said item. Sorry if I offended you for calling your mouse shit when it does what you need of it and you have no reason for it to do anything else, but your mouse doesn't do what I need it to do, so for me, it's useless and something I'd never wish to purchase.

@Vector7 Thanks for the wall of text.

I really mean it, I get your point.

I most surely am a casual gamer, and peripherals really aren't my cup of tea. I'm a datacenter guy, so I'm really into a whole other range of hardware.

Personally I wouldn't call it shit because it's not a $10 no-name chinese generic junk... but yeah... It's a 1000 DPI "self adjusting" mouse. Other than the extra buttons, there's pretty much nothing you can even change.

So just a hot tip for people using spade bits. If you drill a hole and then need to drill it again with a larger bit, instead of bouncing the new bit across your desk or losing a finger trying to hold it, just place a scrap piece of wood or plastic over the hole and drill through it and into the smaller hole. By the time you're through the scrap wood on top, you'll be nicely guided into the desk below. Much neater and safer!

Pro tip for drilling a larger hole in an existing hole. Drill the larger hole through another board first, then lay that board over the smaller hole and use it as a guide. Not ideal for spade bits, but works great for forstner bits and hole saws.

The trick with hot glue is to heat up the mating surfaces before putting on the hot glue. Otherwise the surfaces will cool the hot glue down too quickly and it doesn't have time to bond properly. Also roughing up the mating surfaces to get more surface area helps a lot.

One thing that I have found that works GREAT for mounting stuff is the 3M "command" series of double-sided adhesive.  You don't need the plastic: just buy the refills.  You can use these to mount things to surfaces.  I use them for attaching a USB-C docking station to the back of a monitor.  They also have ones with velcro-style stuff on one side and adhesive on the other.  Perfect for things that you might want to remove occasionally.

This could be made so much better. I have only three cables. This can be reduces to one.

Mouse/pad: there exist wireless mouspads. My mouse have one AA battery. It last for 3-5 month. I use ikea low self dischage batteries with there 12 battry charger. Brilliant.

Keyboard: there exist wireless keyboard.

Screens with built in speakers and usb hubs is not that uncommon.

USB 4.0 can draw 120Watt as well is thunderbalt compatible.. in effect display port copatible.

Now it will not be easy to find a screen suporting all those standars.

Just mount a usb 4 docingport on the backside of the screen. Use a patch cable to feed usb and DP into the screen.

Speakers.. while i also use them seldom, they are really nice to have. But built into screen is really sufficent.

Light and rack for headphones. Just mount the directly to the screen and route the cable atatched to the backside.

Webcam, same thing.

There is really just two things that need not to be atached to the screen. Keyb and mouse.

One more thing. A phone charger stand. Just put it on a bracket on the screen. I use my phone as a DIY webcam. So having a stand with a bracket works really good.

This looks like a "how not to" video.
I would:
1. Pre-place everything on desk. Mark where wires go with a marker.
2. REMOVE everything from desk including metal plates underneath marked holes.
3. drill holes and clean up dust
4. place equipment on desk and run wires to designated attachment points using zip ties and cable ties along the way.
Also, I would consider placing chargers in a separate location if I really wanted to minimize wires at my desk.

Please stop spreading Logitech's marketing bullshit about "better than wired" performance. Of course there are shitty wired mice that a good wireless mouse can outrun, but claims that a wireless mouse can beat an equivalent wired mouse are 100% nonsense.

Plain and simple, if you have two equal mice, one of which has a direct USB interface and one that has a wireless connection to a dongle that then translates to USB the wireless stage can not have negative latency. It might be able to have a low enough latency that it's effectively equal after USB does its thing, but it's literally impossible for it to be lower. When you factor for modulation delays and error correction it gets even worse for wireless.

And yes, I know the speed of light in a cable is slower than the speed of light in air, and over long distances that can actually be enough to make up the difference. Long distances in this case are hundreds of miles/kilometers. High frequency traders care about this. Your mouse does not.

For monitoring the GoXLR via a USB headset it's pretty simple. The "stream mix" comes up in the windows sound control panel as a recording device, not an output device, because of this you can just set "listen to this device" in your sound control panel for the Stream Mix and then set that listen output to your usb-wireless headphones. Problem solved :)
@Farrel Clement Not on my headset. I can't speak for all headsets but I experience 0 delay doing it. Maybe 10ms or less but not enough to be noticable.

A wireless headset with line-in port on the transmitter is a lot better than "listen to this device", still some delay, but nearly as bad.
Or challenge Anthony to use his rPi and Linux skills to make a magic low latency solution, that also works with those newer Logitech transmitters without a line-in.

@Farrel Clement Yep. A nasty delay over 100ms. I've always had that on inputs. Curiously, I have 0 perceivable delay when it's a Playback device that has a Microphone slider in the Levels tab - ie: my USB headset. Not all USB headsets register in Windows this same way.
That leads me to believe Windows CAN do a no-delay monitor, but they don't for some reason.
That usually introduces a delay that makes the experience horrible.

I would like to give others a couple tips that I did when I cable managed my desk. I would highly recommend a Hole saw instead of a spade bit and the use of a regular drill bit to make a Pilot hole for the hole saw. I've gone almost fully wireless or cable-free.

Keyboard, headphones and mouse are Logitech and wireless, and they connect to both my personal PC and my work PC through a USB hub, so I can switch just pressing one button. For the monitor, I am using a dual monitor stand with a really nice able management system and you can only see where they go out at the very bottom of the stand, and this is 2 screens, one of which is connected to 3 sources (my personal rig, work PC and PS4), I have a ambilight-ripoff backlight system, plus a trackir 5 (so 9 cables in total there).
I also have a sound bar which is connected to both the PC and PS4 (no issues here, as only 3 cables going out, and all behind the desk).
Then to charge the headphones, mouse, keyboard, PS4 and XBONE controller and, if needed, my phone and ipad, I have a magnetic plug system with 2 long cables of which you can usually only see the very end of the connector, so I can plug any 2 of these and swap as needed, even if they don't use the same connectors (they use micro-usb, usb-C and lightning respectively).
Finally, all cables are beneath the desk and managed in some racks, and all power cords connected to a power strip attached to the side of the drawers, so the space is completely cable free with the exception of the actual power cord from the strip going into the socket.

I tried the whole "drilling a hole through your desk to hide cables" thing with one of my first mechanical keyboards back in 2014. Except I didn't have a drill at the time (had just graduated college and was living on my own, truly, for the first time) so I just bought the big and used my god damn hand to turn the bit until I got through. I had so many blisters and callouses when I was done, and as I looked upon my newly de-wired desk I....tried to move my keyboard back a little to put a piece of paper in front of me. And realized my mistake. My keyboard was not permanently in that position on my desk. I could move it, sure, but that'd just expose the USB-A connector sized hole in the middle.

1: I recommend an Under Desk Cable Tray for power bricks/cords, I have the ones made by scandinavianhub on Amazon, this paired with a 1U rackmount Cyberpower PDU(Power Distribution Unit) mounted to the bottom of my desk was the cleanest way to get power to everything.
2: I find 3M VHB tape to be the absolute best adhesive for things that you don't want to move around, on top or underneath your desk, it's incredibly strong and the best part is it is still relatively easy to remove with some twisting motion and it does not leave residue or marks upon removal.
3: You can use Voicemeter to use usb headsets with GoXLR if you really wanted to.

For furniture cable management I simply add a few bars (or planks, or staves) running the lengths, and then the occasional hook - and the zip-tie the living daylight out of everything from power bricks to cables to power strips... My first thing is always to just run a high-rated power strip from the easiest-to-hide-the-cables-from-wallsocket (not always the nearest) which makes all the cable mangement a local issue.

And yes, I go through a couple of hundred zip-ties a year (let's just say that even my kitchen drawers have zip-ties and snippers laying in them, as well as that I have a "service kit" for it in a coat pocket (I work with electrical things as well as it, to be able to cable manage on the fly is a great thing (in the service kit I do btw always use light (yellow, white, green, red) zip-ties and have a narrow-tip permanent marker (of the CD marker variety) which allows me to also give everything an id-number)).

To decrease clutter myself, I‚Äôm planning on using a IKEA Galant storage unit with doors, putting my pc and consoles in it, noise dampen the doors, cut ventilation holes (maybe, probably, add fans) and just have a couple of display and usb extension cables (10-15ft) running to my setup.

Eh I don't mind cables, charging everything would annoy me more. The mouse isn't bad though because it charges off the mouse pad, although at that point you are not reducing the cables as you still need a cable to the mouse pad, and you still need cables for charging everything. Unless there was a desk mat that charged everything I couldn't go wireless, and actually that would be awesome as you would only need 1 cable for your peripherals. And 40 hours of charge for a keyboard, remove the RGB and give me a months battery life any day.
